metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (automatic weather station of mixed forest station, 2020)
metadata.description:
This dataset includes data recorded by the Heihe integrated observatory network obtained from the automatic weather station (AWS) at the Sidaoqiao mixed forest station from January 1 to December 31, 2020. The site (101.134° E, 41.990° N) was located on a tamarix and populous forest (Tamarix chinensis Lour. and Populus euphratica Olivier.) surface in the Sidaoqiao, Dalaihubu Town, Ejin Banner, Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region. The elevation is 874 m. The installation heights and orientations of different sensors and measured quantities were as follows: air temperature and humidity profile (28 m, north), wind speed and direction profile (28 m, north), air pressure (in tamper box), rain gauge (28 m, south), four-component radiometer (24 m, south), two infrared temperature sensors (24 m, south, vertically downward), two photosynthetically active radiation (24 m, south, one vertically upward and one vertically downward), soil heat flux (HFP01; 3 duplicates, -0.06 m), soil temperature profile (0, -0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.6, -1.0, -1.6, -2.0, -2.4 m), and soil moisture profile (-0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.6, -1.0, -1.6, -2.0, -2.4 m).
The observations included the following: air temperature and humidity (Ta_28 m; RH_28 m) (℃ and %, respectively), wind speed (Ws_28 m) (m/s), wind direction (WD_28 m) (°), air pressure (press) (hpa), precipitation (rain) (mm), four-component radiation (DR, incoming shortwave radiation; UR, outgoing shortwave radiation; DLR_Cor, incoming longwave radiation; ULR_Cor, outgoing longwave radiation; Rn, net radiation) (W/m^2), infrared temperature (IRT_1 and IRT_2) (℃), photosynthetically active radiation of upward and downward (PAR_up and PAR_down) (μmol/ (s m^-2)), soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2 and Gs_3) (W/m^2), soil temperature (Ts_0 cm, Ts_2 cm, Ts_4 cm, Ts_10 cm, Ts_20 cm, Ts_40 cm, Ts_60 cm, Ts_100, Ts_160, Ts_200, Ts_240 cm) (℃), and soil moisture (Ms_2 cm, Ms_4 cm, Ms_10 cm, Ms_20 cm, Ms_40 cm, Ms_60 cm, Ms_100, Ms_160, Ms_200, Ms_240 cm) (%, volumetric water content).
The data processing and quality control steps were as follows: (1) The AWS data were averaged over intervals of 10 min for a total of 144 records per day. The missing data were denoted by -6999. Due to the power loss, there were occasionally data missing in January. Due to the sensor malfunction, the wind direction and soil temperature at 240 cm depth during January to June and soil temperature at 10 cm depth were missing. (2) Data in duplicate records were rejected. (3) Unphysical data were rejected. (4) The data marked in red are problematic data. (5) The format of the date and time was unified, and the date and time were collected in the same column, for example, date and time: 2020-9-10 10:30. (6) Finally, the naming convention was AWS+ site no. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a dataset that includes long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Example.Answer: A dataset that includes long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is available from the study area comprising the middle and lower reaches of the Heihe River Basin (HRB) in western China. This dataset includes data from 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations established since 2012, capturing energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes as well as hydrometeorological data.

Example.Question: What is an example of a data collection method used to gather information on soil parameters in arid regions?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method for gathering soil parameters in arid regions involves using automatic weather stations to observe soil temperature profiles and soil moisture profiles, as well as using soil heat flux plates. These parameters are typically measured at different depths to understand the soil's thermal and moisture conditions.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a challenge faced in maintaining data quality for meteorological observations in arid regions?
Example.Answer: A challenge faced in maintaining data quality for meteorological observations in arid regions is the occurrence of data gaps due to power supply issues, as seen in the dataset from the Heihe River Basin where data from January 1-14 showed interruptions. Additionally, issues with sensors such as those measuring wind direction or soil temperature can also lead to data quality challenges.

Definition.Question: What does 'eddy covariance system' mean in the context of data collection for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange?
Definition.Answer: In the context of data collection for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, an 'eddy covariance system' refers to a method for measuring and calculating the turbulent fluxes of these components between the land surface and atmosphere. It involves using instruments that capture high-frequency wind and scalar data to compute the covariance between vertical wind speed and scalar quantities like CO2 concentration, thus enabling the study of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange processes.

Definition.Question: What does 'comprehensive observation network' mean in the context of environmental data collection?
Definition.Answer: In the context of environmental data collection, a 'comprehensive observation network' refers to a coordinated system of multiple observation sites and instruments designed to systematically monitor various environmental parameters such as meteorological, hydrological, and ecological data across a specific region. This network aims to provide integrated datasets that facilitate the understanding of complex environmental processes and interactions.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection techniques used at the Heihe River Basin meteorological stations compare to those used in other oasis-desert systems with respect to measuring energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange?
Comparison.Answer: In the Heihe River Basin, data collection involves automatic weather stations measuring meteorological parameters with 10-minute averages, similar to other oasis-desert systems where hydrometeorological data, including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, are collected. However, the specific setup, such as the use of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers in some studies, may vary.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways could long-term observational data from automated weather stations contribute to understanding the ecological and socioeconomic dynamics of oasis-desert systems?
Interpretation.Answer: Long-term observational data from automated weather stations can provide critical insights into the ecological balance and sustainability of oasis-desert systems by capturing trends in energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges. This understanding can inform strategies for achieving carbon neutrality and ecological security, which are vital for the socioeconomic development of these regions.

Specifically, problems with wind direction sensors and soil temperature sensors have been noted, which can impact the reliability of the collected data.

Causal Antecedent.Answer: Long-term observation is considered indispensable for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems because it provides a comprehensive understanding of the basic characteristics and interactions within these systems. This understanding is crucial to achieving sustainable oasis development and supporting ecological security, particularly in the context of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality goals.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers in data collection for oasis–desert ecosystems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: These tools allow for the acquisition of half-hourly turbulent flux data, providing critical insights into the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in oasis–desert areas, which are essential for understanding interactions and sustainability in these ecosystems.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of long-term observations in oasis–desert areas for addressing environmental degradation challenges in arid and semiarid regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Long-term observations are indispensable for maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems, helping to mitigate crises such as land desertification and dust storms, and supporting the sustainable development of these critical ecological landscapes.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it crucial to understand the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems within the context of global climate change?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives behind establishing long-term observational datasets for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in arid regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are implemented to ensure data quality and control when observing meteorological elements at an automatic weather station in arid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedures for ensuring data quality and control include ensuring the collection of 144 data points per day, marking missing data with -6999, removing duplicate records, deleting data that exceed physical or instrument limits, marking questionable data in red, and standardizing the date and time format.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What data collection methods are used to observe energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems, and how are these observations integrated into a comprehensive dataset?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Data collection methods used include the use of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for flux measurements, and automatic weather stations for hydrometeorological data with a 10-minute average period. These observations are integrated into a comprehensive dataset by combining energy, water vapor, and carbon flux data with auxiliary data on hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters, and applying a structured data processing, quality control, and archiving procedure.

Enablement.Question: What data collection methods enable the comprehensive monitoring of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: The data collection methods include the use of an eddy covariance system, scintillometer, and automatic weather stations to acquire half-hourly turbulent flux data and hydrometeorological data with a 10-minute average period. These methods provide detailed observations involving radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, air temperature, humidity gradients, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles.

Enablement.Question: How do specific observational setups, such as sensor placement and calibration, enable accurate data acquisition in arid and semiarid regions?
Enablement.Answer: In the mixed forest station of the Heihe River Basin, sensors for air temperature and relative humidity are mounted at 28m, while wind sensors and tipping bucket rain gauges are positioned similarly to ensure consistent data capture. Soil temperature and moisture sensors are strategically buried at various depths to accurately profile subsurface conditions, enhancing the reliability and accuracy of the data collected.

Enablement.Question: What technological and methodological advancements are crucial for maintaining long-term ecological monitoring in the context of oasis–desert interactions?
Enablement.Answer: Long-term ecological monitoring is supported by advanced technologies such as automatic weather stations, which provide continuous hydrometeorological data collection, and the integration of auxiliary data on vegetation and soil parameters. The use of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for energy, water vapor, and carbon flux measurements is also crucial, along with data processing, quality control, and data archiving techniques to ensure data accuracy and availability.

Expectation.Question: Why might the data collection methods for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems need to incorporate multiple observational datasets and auxiliary data?
Expectation.Answer: Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is crucial to maintaining the balance between these systems and supporting ecological security. A comprehensive suite of observational datasets, including hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters, provides a quantitative understanding that is significant for recognizing oasis–desert interactions and protecting ecological stability.

Expectation.Question: What challenges might arise in maintaining a consistent and accurate dataset of meteorological observations in arid and semiarid regions?
Expectation.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas face ecological degradation challenges such as river drying, vegetation degradation, and intensified land desertification, which can affect data consistency and accuracy. Observational data may experience issues like missing or erroneous data due to environmental conditions, instrument malfunctions, or data transmission failures.

Expectation.Question: Why is it important for datasets covering oasis–desert areas to undergo rigorous data processing and quality control procedures?
Expectation.Answer: Rigorous data processing and quality control are essential to ensure the dataset's reliability and accuracy, especially given the critical role these datasets play in understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange for maintaining ecological stability and supporting socio-economic development in oasis–desert areas. This involves removing duplicate records, correcting erroneous data, and ensuring consistent data formatting.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using automated weather stations and eddy covariance systems for collecting comprehensive data on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of automated weather stations and eddy covariance systems appears effective for collecting comprehensive data on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, as they provide detailed hydrometeorological data and turbulent fluxes essential for understanding oasis–desert interactions. These methods allow for continuous long-term observations, which are crucial for evaluating ecological stability and socioeconomic development in these regions.

Assertion.Answer: A dataset in the context of oasis–desert systems can effectively measure and balance energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges by using long-term observational data, such as those from artificial and natural systems, capturing fluxes and auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters. The use of an eddy covariance system and scintillometer for acquiring half-hourly turbulent flux data, along with hydrometeorological observations from automatic weather stations, enables comprehensive monitoring and analysis of these exchanges.

This includes measurements of radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, and gradients of air temperature and humidity, which are complemented by the deployment of sensors at various soil depths and precise data processing and quality control procedures.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and discuss the challenges faced in data collection for inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas, focusing on ecological environment degradation.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in data collection for inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas include ecological degradation issues such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These challenges are exacerbated in many inland river basins along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin, the Aral Sea basin, and the Lake Urmia basin. Accurate data collection is crucial to address these issues and support sustainable development in these regions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential datasets and their significance for studying the balance between oasis and desert systems to achieve sustainable development goals.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets for studying the balance between oasis and desert systems include those containing observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, as well as auxiliary data on hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters. These datasets, available from sources like the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center, are significant for understanding ecosystem interactions, supporting ecological security, and achieving sustainable development goals by providing critical insights into the dynamics of oasis-desert systems.
